item.title: beat generation
item.description: subculture movement started by a group of authors whose work explored and influenced American culture and politics in the post-war era

item.title: Bloomsbury Group
item.description: was a group of associated English writers, intellectuals, philosophers and artists in the first half of the 20th century According to Ian Ousby, “although its members denied being a group in any formal sense, they were united by an abiding belief in the importance of the arts.

item.title: Girish Karnad
item.description: renowned playwright, activist, director, and actor many languages; Kannada, English, Hindi won Karnataka Sahitya Academy Award for [[Nagamandala]] loved Tipu Sultan

item.title: The Moon and Sixpence
item.description: Author: W Somerset Maugham Plot Summary About the life of Charles Strickland, a fictional artist modeled after Paul Gauguin. Narrator talks about uniqueness of Strickland and his intensity for work.

item.title: Jayanta Mahapatra
item.description: is an Indian poet awarded Padma Shri; returned it in 2015 as a protest against rising intolerance awarded Sahitya Akademi Award

item.title: Literary Movements
item.description: Old English 450-1066 Middle English 1066-1500 The Renaissance 1500-1660 The Elizabethan Age 1558-1603 The Jacobean Age 1603-1625 The Restoration Period 1660-1700

item.title: Allen Ginsberg
item.description: Beat Generation Poet Counterculture Openly gay Known for raw - grotesque - unrefined - gritty poetry meant to be heard, not read

item.title: anaphora
item.description: In rhetoric, an anaphora (Greek, “carrying back”) is a rhetorical device that consists of repeating a sequence of words at the beginnings of neighboring clauses

item.title: John Lennon
item.description: Part of The Beatles Married Yoko Ono

item.title: Mark Twain
item.description: Mark Twain born Samuel Langhorne Clemens writer - satirist - one of the greatest American writers and the father of American literature

item.title: Symbols, Motifs, and Themes
item.description: Symbols, motifs, and themes are often confused with each other. Though they share similarities, they are vastly different. Themes are abstract ideas

item.title: Character of Dogs
item.description: Character of Dogs By [[Robert Louis Stevenson]] published in Memories and Portraits a collection of essays by Stevenson first published in 1887

item.title: Robert Louis Stevenson
item.description: Scottish novelist, essayist, poet and travel writer known for Treasure Island; The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde

item.title: America by Allen Ginsberg
item.description: America by [[Allen Ginsberg]] - Beat generation poet; [[Stream of Consciousness]] - ramblings - raw - grotesque - unrefined hoped to get out not narrative or beauty but spontaneity, human expression, and reaction

item.title: George Bernard Shaw
item.description: Playwright Born in Dublin Grew up in poverty Dad was alcoholic

item.title: Pygmalion
item.description: Pygmalion Play Written by [[George Bernard Shaw]] in 1912 ![[inbox/unprocessed/Victorian Era]] Title is based on Greek mythology Pygamlion - a sculptor; makes an ivory statue representing ideal womanhood; falls in love w his own creation,

item.title: Virginia Woolf
item.description: Feminist Modernist writer pioneer in use of [[Stream of Consciousness]] as a narrative device Part of [[Bloomsbury Group]] husband Leonard Woolf started Hogarth Press w Leonard Woolf Most famous works - novels - Mrs Dalloway and To the Lighthouse

item.title: WB Yeats
item.description: Irish poet - Irish Nationalist Symbolist Inspired by Pre-Raphaelites and William Blake poetry was a reaction to the naturalistic and realistic poetry of the Victorian age
